is the main county in the Peninsula region.  While many of the Peninsula's residents work and play to the north or south, the Peninsula has its attractions, including some beautiful wilderness areas. 

The
has two coasts—one on the San Francisco Bay, the other on the Pacific Ocean—but few major cities or ports. The
divide the region in half north-south, with a large wilderness area that's great for hiking and mountain biking.

All three airports are served by public transportation.  The regional metro-rail service BART runs directly to SFO and connects to the commuter rail line Caltrain, as does the San Mateo County bus service SamTrans.  The East Bay bus service AC Transit and a connecting bus to BART, AirBART, run to OAK.  Santa Clara County's Valley Transportation Authority runs a bus (Line 10) connecting SJC with Caltrain and that county's light rail and bus system.

Motorists can reach the Peninsula from OAK by crossing the bay on the

(Highway 84, farther to the south).  From SJC, drivers can take Highway 87 to US-101 northward, although avoiding 101's rush-hour traffic is often recommended. (For longer trips northward, try the scenic, parallel Interstate 280.)

runs up and down the peninsula between San Francisco and San Jose, stopping at most major towns and serving the  San Jose International Airport (via a short transit bus at Santa Clara station). Some trains continue further south to Gilroy. It runs 7 days a week until about 1am (10pm on Sundays). If you've missed the last Caltrain, local bus service is available all night.
serves a small portion of the peninsula, with some trains terminating at either San Francisco Airport or Millbrae. Caltrain and BART connect at Millbrae.

value: http://www.samtrans.com/ San Mateo County Transit District

runs extensive bus service throughout San Mateo county, plus overlaps in Palo Alto and San Francisco. Some bus routes run all night. Normal bus fare is $2.00, express buses are $5.00, and Clipper cards are accepted. Useful bus routes include:

value: - Palo Alto Caltrain to Daly City BART, along El Camino Real. Stops at Millbrae
- Redwood City Caltrain to downtown San Francisco, along El Camino Real
- Combination of 390 and 391, late-night service. Stops at most Caltrain stations - useful for when Caltrain has stopped running.
- Express service from San Francisco to Palo Alto Caltrain, stopping at San Francisco Airport
- Downtown San Francisco to San Francisco Airport

runs buses throughout Santa Clara County, starting in Palo Alto. Normal bus fare is $2.00, express is $4.00, and Clipper is accepted. Routes that serve the Peninsula include:

value: - Palo Alto Caltrain to Downtown San Jose, along El Camino.

The two main highways running down the peninsula are 101 and 280. If you are driving from

, take I-280. It is a beautiful drive, free of advertising, well above the wilderness area. If you must drive on 101, avoid rush hour - it will be slow in both directions. The drive along the coast on State Route 1 (the Cabrillo Highway) is a beautiful, yet slow drive.

Many streets throughout the Peninsula have designated bike lanes, helping make cycling on the peninsula safer and easier. Key north-south bike routes include Alameda de las Pulgas, Middlefield Avenue, and Cañada Road.

About 30% of the Peninsula is nature preserve, parkland, or otherwise undeveloped. There are many opportunities for hiking and mountain biking, all a short drive away. The transition from the crowded town along the eastern coast to empty wilderness is a rapid one! Most parks are managed by the

, while some are part of local towns or counties. Almost every park permits mountain biking, and most allow horseback riding.

content=This park combines dense redwood groves adjacent to wide-open grasslands. A good choice if you can't make it to Muir Woods.

Be careful to check for ticks

after hiking in fields in the bay area.  There is a high rate of lyme disease transmission in the Bay Area.  If a bulls' eye rash develops at the tick bite site, immediately seek medical help and treatment with antibiotics.
